newsitem.title: UK: Oman minister reaffirms India gas pipeline shelved.
newsitem.headline: Oman minister reaffirms India gas pipeline shelved.

text.p: The Oman-India subsea natural gas pipeline project was still shelved, a minister said on Friday, despite an Indian official's claim to the contrary.

"It is not worth continuing to spend money on developing the technology (for the Oman-India project) for the time being," Oman's minister of state for development affairs Mohamed Musa al-Yousef said at a press conference.
Yousef was in London to meet investors ahead of Oman's debut international bond issue, expected in the first week of March.
There have been conflicting reports about whether or not the project was still under development.
In December Oman said it had shelved the project due to technical difficulties after spending over $60 million on feasibility studies.
But in February, the chairman of India's state-run Gas Authority of India Ltd (GAIL) said it had not been abandoned and a lot of technical issues were already resolved.
Oman is currently developing a $6.0 billion liquefied natural gas (LNG) project, due to start operation in 2000.
"Since we have gone for other projects, like the LNG project, there won't even be that much gas to provide for the Indian pipeline, and it is a very complicated technology," Yousef said.
